comment: Participate in the discussion boards and keep up for a pretty easy A.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Clear grading criteria

comment: I had no idea what the point of this class was. I DO know that this is not some science class. It's like a philosophy class of some sort. I took this class 100% online, worst decision ever. The professor responds to emails on her own time they go unanswered. As the class goes on the readings get lengthy. PLEASE JUST PICK ANOTHER CLASS.
Online class- decent amount of reading. Open book tests. Do the discussion posts and it's a pretty easy A.

It's an online class, so it feels like all "homework." There's a discussion board, and if you do the readings and post weekly it's a pretty easy A as long as you don't fall behind. There are also 3 quizzes, but they are open book. I thought the topic was pretty interesting.

Someone in her family is sick which she can't prevent & I do understand- just know that she won't grade things/ respond to emails for a long time. Mostly reading & discussions. Buy the textbook. We haven't had a test grade all semester. Little to no engagement from the prof.
A decent amount of reading. Graded on discussion posts and three tests, but they are open book. I didn't know what to expect with the class, but I ended up pretty interested in the topic.

I really didn't like this as an online course. But, as long as you do the readings and respond on the discussion board, the grading is pretty easy. I do think the class would be better with some in person time for discussions.
Online class- discussion posts every week. Easy A if you just do the reading and discussion posts. There are 3 tests, but they are open book.

Professor Bradfield was hard to get in contact with, especially at the beginning of the semester. There was a discussion post due every week, with extremely long readings and she was often very late on posting the prompts for the week. The tests are open note. She did post a study guide for every test, but I did not find them very helpful.
Just do the online posting. The tests are also open book- it was a pretty easy A - just have to keep up.

A little confusing at first, but I'm not used to online classes. But, I ended up liking the class. It was tied to current events, and pretty easy to make an A if you just do all the assignments. The study guides tell you what is on the test.

This class was entirely online, and I feel like it would be better as a hybrid at least. But, the pandemic made that not an option. I think this made it more difficult to get the more complicated topics, but the tests were easy as long as you filled out the study guide. Those made for a pretty easy A. And, the topics were pretty interesting.
Online class- Some topics are not completely clear- would probably be better as a hybrid class with some in person meetings. But, easy A so far with just following study guides and power points.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things

comment: I was a little worried because of the wide variety of ratings from last semester. It looks like the transition from hybrid to online (due to COVID) was confusing for the spring. This class is now entirely online, is easy to follow, and is interesting. I have an A (so far), and I'd take this professor again.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Graded by few things--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: Honestly, I have to say that she was not a bad professor. People need to realize that these professors have lives outside of school like all of us. She was not as responsive as other professors but I believed she was still accessible and very respectful. She's very smart and knowledgable about different materials. Overall I would take her again.

This Professor had a "Medical issue" and did not tell anyone for 2 and a half months. All of my classmate's grades suffered because of it. She hardly replies to emails. She did not attempt to make announcements this semester. In fact, there was no announcement for the final exam at all, even after several emails were sent by 2 students and myself.

PLEASE AVOID. Shes a nice but her teaching habits are terribly inconsistent. During COVID she was unresponsive and completely lacked a plan. Frankly, she lacked a plan for the class even while on campus. Save yourself the confusion and headache! Youll NEVER know your grade if you take her class. AVOID at all costs.

She is a very nice woman and attendance was not mandatory. The class is a hybrid and consists of weekly discussion posts, 3 exams, and a few other assignments (that were made optional due to covid). However, you have to teach yourself everything. She will not reply to emails, and will not grade assignments quickly at all.

Hybrid class- I felt like we needed more in class time because some of the topics were confusing. Study guides and power points were very helpful. Professor did extra study sessions in person for the class also which helped. I learned a lot, but it was harder than I expected.

This was a hybrid class. Keep up with the online posts and do the reading. Interesting topic. Tests cover a lot of material, but if you follow the study guide you can make an A. This was a gen ed class, but I liked it ok and learned A LOT.

I've only been in this class for a few weeks and this class blows. She doesn't have set schedule for the class in the syllabus; only goes by module. This class is a 66% hybrid class, so you would think she would post stuff online-NOPE. You would honestly be better off taking this class fully online if any of this stuff doesn't interest you.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lecture heavy
